children.subject:
I see it like this:

Best Case - EECS would just allow students to ignore this semester's courses in their GPA calculation and declare based on whatever other graded courses they have. (Alternative: Allow students to substitute other EECS Courses, like EE16A/B, etc. in for the classes that were forced P/NP)

Pros: Fair and equal/Does not put the burden on students to remedy the issues.

Cons: Would advantage students who overloaded on EECS Courses/If a student was counting on a good grade this semester to boost GPA, it would not happen.

Medium Case - Make students retake courses or base grades on a final/placement course-subject-spanning assessment

Pros: No free lunch

Cons: Guaranteed to deflate GPAs if too granular in the mapping, but the same goes for the other way. Also causes grade to depend entirely on one event.

Worst Case - SAT-style placement test that decided if you could declare

Pros: Tests overall CS knowledge to assess aptitude

Cons: Puts all merit on a single event, severe anxiety inducer/stressor, Completely changes the standard that declaration is based upon.

I think there may be a solution that we let students to choose what courses they want to PNP and restrict the number of  PNP courses this semester. For example, all students have to choose 1-2 courses to PNP and other courses letter graded. In this case, if students need grades to declare or boost GPA, they can choose to PNP other courses and letter grade those "essential" courses. In the meantime, as all students PNP 1-2 courses, all can be less stressed. Moreover, if all courses have optional policy on PNP (you can PNP as many as you want), for people trying to go to grad school, they may just feel pressured to take it for letter grade. But as we enforce PNP 1-2 courses, people could choose to PNP some courses without thinking about bad consequences of PNP. Just a thought.
Although I see your point, I have had an EECS class compensate with the "take-home" nature of our midterm by making it longer and more difficult (in other words, more rigorous).

I feel like this petition is reasonable. Firstly, MIT already did it. Secondly, the pandemic makes students unable to focus on coursework. Lastly, the tests this semester are not as rigorous as usual. Some classes offer exams without proctoring, some classes simply cancel later exams, which put students who did not do well on the first exam at severe disadvantage, some classes potentially push midterm to a date after pass/no pass deadline which we can't decide whether to pass/no pass it or letter grade it.

Thanks for your reply!

I think you have a point in regards to the PNP thing--how do you think EECS should handle the change?

Do you think you could provide a source for the actions taken by MIT? I can't seem to easily find it online.

https://facultygovernance.mit.edu/message-chair

Point number 7, and I believe MIT operates in the semester system as well.

I think the only way to make this fair is to do mandatory PNP for all similar to what MIT did. 

As much as I worked hard this semester, even if we do voluntary PNP (which is what UCB is leaning towards currently) it will only cause more stress for students. If we mandate everyone to do PNP, graduate schools can't distinguish between those who had the choice vs those who couldn't. If this policy is done to make it less stressful for students a mandatory PNP is the only sensible idea. 

Think about it, if you were given the option to PNP a class, a student will be stressed by the fact that they had the choice. In fact, this is mentioned in the MIT letter

(6) The Team was advised that giving students a letter grade "opt in" choice would in fact lead to increased stress and anxiety for many students. For example, some students would feel pressured to choose to opt in for a letter grade because not doing so would be interpreted to mean that their performance was not strong.

I know students will hate me for this, but its the only fair thing I see. Making things voluntary will only induce more stress and I think MIT nailed it.

I think so long as instructors and the EECS understand why the curve is high and respond accordingly, I don't really see why a higher curve during this strange semester makes a difference (EECS could forgo its ideal B/B+ grade average for just one semester), it's more about the individual students’ performance at this point and how they can get the most from the class, since we are all damaged by in this situation yet are still paying tuition. Some students not only want to complete coursework but also need the grade (e.g. what about the students who really need a certain grade to lift them up this semester so they can graduate? What will forcing them to take a PNP do to their situation?). Some students are having an unusually rough time and definitely want to take the PNP option (which they can anyway, even in a regular semester), they just shouldn't be penalized by not having their class count for their major. If students feel pressured to keep a letter grade (bc they want to go to grad. school or whatever it may be), that's still their choice (and I think grad school admissions teams will recognize that Sp2020 was a bad semester, so whatever the students’ decision, it would be justifiable)--if you enforce PNP, or any one option for that matter, they don't get a choice; and yet they will still be paying for this semester's tuition. I think regardless of curves or how other students will perform relative to each other, the issue is whether to allow PNP to fulfill major reqs. (since they can always PNP but it would only be different this semester by allowing this to still count for their major). Other interesting alternatives posed included not going to PNP but instead shifting letter grade bins up for everyone, essentially making it slightly easier to get any given grade and in doing so still maintaining a natural grade distribution, meaning students with strong grades wont just give up their effort since they already know they'll pass, and students with bad situations can try as much as they can and still get a pretty good grade (it's just that the curve will be high, but it will be high for everyone). Or, the school can just keep the letter grade-default option and tell all instructors to lighten/adjust their grading policies, as many schools have already done, so that students' grades don't just drop. Since so many people have different opinions, different situations and different plans, and have courses of vastly different structure, I'm not sure why changes shouldn't just made by instructors on a class-by-class basis, taking into account feedback from their students, rather than choosing one policy for everyone.

I personally agree with what MIT did—it’s fair to everyone.  My TA brought up a great point today about only allowing pass/fail: if a student gets an A this semester based on an online exam, that would definitely not be fair to someone who got an A in the same class last semester. Let’s be real here—there’s a much, much lower chance of cheating in in-person exams. Also by giving the students a choice, we are only adding to the stress. With that said, I acknowledge that we all have our own unique opinions, so I guess we just have to wait to see what the administration decides.

This is a tricky situation and I understand all the perspectives offered so far. However as a graduating senior, I'd like to offer my own perspective. Making Pass/Fail required prevents me and others like me from improving our GPA when this is our last chance to do so.

As much as I understand boosting your GPA -- not everyone will be happy. COVID-19 affects everyone very differently. Those affected the most will possibly PNP while those fortunate enough not to have been affected will elect for a letter. a mandatory PNP seems the most fair. there isn't a plan that suits everyone, but at least we can be fair.

What about people in L&S who need a good grade in their final CS prereq to declare? Wouldn't it be unfair to them if they couldn't declare just because they got unlucky and took the last prereq this semester?

Like I said, not everyone will be happy. I understand the anxiety that you must go through declaring and ideally the EECS department will do something to address this. I just think this is the most fair and best course of action that can be fair to the most amount of people with several different circumstances.

I see your point and I do agree that it is fair given the situation for the most part, but it kind of takes away from those who worked very hard to get great grades before this pandemic started and now we have to surrender that grade due to an event out of our control. I do understand the other side as well, but I guess I'm trying to highlight that there is 2 sides to this that will be heavily impacted

I do support mandatory p/np, however, if it is deemed fairer to those who are more disadvantaged by this epidemic than I currently am. Just hoping the policy has a way of not hurting those who worked for a grade they had in mind during the start of the semester and continued to work for just to get a passing grade for it.

I think the optional choice that the university is making is actually hurting the people who had their hearts set on a grade...the curves are worse...I also worked really hard in the early parts of the semester, and would be sad about my effort not being reflected. But P/NP for all or no action at all is definitely the best...

if u haven't read the MIT letter, here's the link, they write it out BEAUTIFULLY...

https://facultygovernance.mit.edu/message-chair

I really hope they either make it mandatory or they don't do anything at all. While giving the option might seem nice, it really isn't

- Firstly, this is inevitably going to preasure students into taking the grading option because Grad schools would definitely look down upon P/NP, if it wasn't required for the entire university.

- Secondly, curves will be really skewed. Presumably, the people who do choose to take the graded option will be more confident that they can get a higher grade in the class, which means curves will be unusually high.
https://www.northwestern.edu/coronavirus-covid-19-updates/developments/updates/winter-finals-policy.html
This is even more unreasonable. The pandemic occurred before our semester even got to midterm, do you mean the first 1/3 indicates how students will do in the later parts?

+1 to above.

It's not fair to compare out situation with a quarter system.

I saw that some schools that are on the quarter system began to make exams optional for students. Those who decide to do the final assignments/exams can use those grades in their final grade for the quarter, but those who decide not to can just keep their current grade before this whole pandemic started. 

I see that as another potential option - it seems to be a good indicator of how well students were performing in certain classes before we had all these outside stressors.

history.content:
Hello!

      Though highly unlikely to occur at a university like UCB, there is currently a petition going around to "Change UC Berkeley Spring Grades to be Pass/No-Pass AND Counted as Major Requirements." There are, however, already discussions happening at schools across the US, and the University of Toronto has already made this exact change.  I'm not here to ask if this is going to happen--It's far too volatile of an issue to accurately pin-down--but rather to pose a more philosophical problem: how would the EECS department be affected by such a change?

      Every undergrad is in a different phase of their degree, and for those who have not yet declared, each one would have holes in different places. For example, one student may be taking no classes required to declare, while someone else who planned poorly and took them all in the same semester could theoretically pass them all and have no average GPA for the courses. Ignoring the odds of this taking place and given the chaotic times we inhabit, it would be reassuring to know that the EECS department has plans to approach this--like with the 10-hour-TA issue--rather than getting blindsided and forced to come up with a quick fix.

      Students will be declaring at the end of the semester, so if something like this was handed down from admin, the department would be limited in their available time to react, especially given the level of anxiety-ridden-queries they would recieve from the thousands of undeclared CS-intended undergrads. How do you all think EECS and L&S could rationally react while still remaining fair to as many students as possible?
history.subject: Force All Grading to be P/NP this Semester Petition -- Impact on L&S CS Majors

history.subject: P/NP Semester Impact
